Title:
Morphological and phylogenetic characterization of
wood-inhabiting fungi of the Schizoporaceae (Polyporales): introducing
three new Xylodon species from the southern China
Keywords:
Corticioid fungi; Xylodon; Schizoporaceae; Molecular
systematics; Taxonomy; Yunnan Province
Abstract:
Wood-inhabiting fungi play crucial roles as decomposers in
forest ecosystems, and three new corticioid fungi, Xylodon gossypiuus,
X. macrosporus and X. sinensis spp. nov. are here proposed based on a
combination of morphological features and molecular evidence. X.
gossypiuus is characterized by resupinate basidiomata with cream when
fresh, buff upon drying hymenial surface, cystidia of three types and
elliptic to subglobose basidiospores. X. macrosporus is characterized by
resupinate basidiomata with tuberculate to minutely-grandinioid hymenial
surface, cystidia of three types and subglobose to globose
basidiospores. X. sinensis is characterized by basidiomata resupinate,
adnate, coriaceous with tuberculate to minutely-grandinioid hymenial
surface and ellipsoid to ovoid basidiospores. Sequences of ITS, nLSU and
ITS+nLSU rRNA markers of the studied samples were generated, and
phylogenetic analyses were performed with maximum likelihood, maximum
parsimony, and Bayesian inference methods. These analyses showed that
the three new species clustered into Xylodon, in which based on the
ITS+nLSU dataset and LSU sequences, X. gossypiuus was sister to X.
borealis, X. macrosporus formed a sister group to X. follis and X.
sinensis formed a monophyletic lineage and based on the ITS sequences,
X. gossypiuus was sister to X. borealis, X. macrosporus was sister to X.
follis and X. sinensis formed a sister group to X. rimosissimus.
